questions.text: A 37-year-old woman is brought to the physician for worsening depressed mood and irritability. Her mood changes began several months ago. Her husband has also noticed shaky movements of her limbs and trunk for the past year. The patient has no suicidal ideation. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her father died by suicide at the age of 45 years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 128/72 mm Hg. She speaks slowly and quietly and only looks at the floor. She registers 3/3 words but can recall only one word 5 minutes later. Examination shows irregular movements of the arms and legs at rest. Extraocular eye movements are normal. Slit-lamp examination shows no abnormalities. Muscle strength is 5/5 throughout, and deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Babinski sign indicates an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Other common UMN signs include weakness, hyperreflexia, and spasticity. Although patients with advanced HD may develop UMN signs, the later stages of the disease are usually characterized by hypokinetic motor symptoms rather than chorea. A Babinski sign might develop later in the course of the disease, but it is an unlikely finding at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid are characteristic of multiple sclerosis (MS). This patient's neurological symptoms are chronic and progressive without focal deficits, which is uncommon for MS. In addition, MS does not typically cause choreoathetoid movements.

C) INCORRECT:

Temporoparietal hypometabolism on PET scan is characteristic of Alzheimer disease (AD), which is a common cause of short term memory loss (e.g., poor word recall) and is frequently associated with depressive symptoms. However, AD typically affects patients > 65 years of age and manifests with pronounced language and temporospatial symptoms (e.g., disorientation). In addition, AD does not cause choreoathetoid movements.

D) CORRECT:

Atrophy of the striatum, especially in the caudate nucleus, with consequent enlargement of ventricles (i.e., ex vacuo ventriculomegaly) is characteristic of HD. Neuroimaging is primarily used to rule out other intracranial causes of a patient's symptoms rather than to diagnose HD. When HD is suspected, genetic testing (e.g., via PCR) is the test of choice.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted FSPGR; coronal view)

There is an enlargement of the ventricles and subarachnoid space as well as volume loss of cortex and caudate nuclei heads (green overlay) that usually have a convex shape (dotted white line). These findings are typical of general cerebral atrophy. The frontal horns of the lateral ventricles (gray hatched overlay) are enlarged due to the cerebral atrophy, giving them a box-like configuration.

This condition is known as hydrocephalus ex vacuo. These findings in a patient with chorea are consistent with Huntington disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased ceruloplasmin is characteristic of Wilson disease (WD), which leads to copper accumulation in certain parts of the CNS (e.g., subcortical white matter, cerebral cortex, basal ganglia), causing symptoms similar to those seen in HD (i.e., mood changes, cognitive impairment, and movement disorders). The vast majority of patients with WD who have neurological symptoms also present with Kayser-Fleischer rings on slit-lamp examination. The absence of Kayser-Fleischer rings in this patient makes WD unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's chorea (e.g., involuntary limb and trunk movements), depression, irritability, and cognitive impairment (e.g., word recall difficulty) are suggestive of Huntington disease (HD).

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of a 1-year history of abnormal behavior. During this time she has been irritable, and restless, and has had multiple episodes of hearing voices. Over the past month, she has also had difficulty swallowing. She has a 2-year history of depression. She was let go by her employer 6 months ago because she could no longer handle all her tasks and often forgot about assignments. Her father died by suicide at the age of 50 years. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily over the past 20 years. She has a history of smoking cocaine for 8 years but stopped 1 year ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she is confused and oriented to person and place only. Neurologic examination shows a delayed return to neutral ankle position after triggering the plantar reflex. Physical examination shows irregular, nonrepetitive, and arrhythmic movements of the neck and head. The patient has poor articulation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with Wilson disease may present with mood changes, dysarthria, movement disorders, cognitive impairment, and depression. However, motor symptoms typically include asymmetrical tremor, parkinsonism, and/or dystonia; choreiform movements would be unlikely. In addition, the condition usually presents earlier in life (between 5 and 35 years) and is associated with characteristic physical exam findings of copper accumulation (e.g., Kayser-Fleischer rings, hepatomegaly, jaundice), which are not seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Sydenham chorea is a movement disorder that is associated with rheumatic fever and manifests with speech disorders, neuropsychiatric symptoms (e.g., agitation, anxiety), and involuntary choreiform movements similar to those seen in this patient. However, rheumatic fever usually affects children between 5 and 15 years of age, not adults. Moreover, symptoms of Sydenham chorea typically occur within 6 months after an infection with S. pyogenes (most commonly pharyngitis), whereas this patient's symptoms have had a relatively slow progression (over two years). Also, dysphagia, depression, and/or cognitive impairment are not classically seen in Sydenham chorea.

C) INCORRECT:

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a neurodegenerative disease that may also manifest with hallucinations, depression, involuntary movements, and mood changes. However, this disease usually progresses much faster than this patient's condition, with an average life expectancy of fewer than 12 months following symptom onset. While choreiform movements can occur in CJD, myoclonic movements are far more common. Furthermore, this patient does not present other clinical features of CJD, such as mutism, seizures, and gait disturbance.

D) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease (PD) can also present with a slow progression of involuntary movements with lower limb rigidity, dysphagia, depression, cognitive impairment, dysarthria, and mood disorders. However, this patient is younger than most individuals at symptom onset of PD (age of onset ∼ 60 years) and her physical exam shows choreiform movements rather than the typical 4–6 Hz pill-rolling hand tremor and bradykinesia.

E) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) also commonly occurs in women between 20–40 years of age and manifests with depression, dysphagia, cognitive impairment, hyperreflexia, and speech impairment. However, MS is usually characterized by episodes of demyelination symptoms (e.g., loss of proprioception or vibration, Lhermitte sign, upper motor neuron weakness), cranial nerve palsy, intention tremor, and/or ophthalmological symptoms (optic neuritis, internuclear ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus), not by choreiform movements. Symptomatic episodes of MS are classically separated by periods of remission; progressive symptoms, as seen in this patient, are less common.

F) INCORRECT:

Cocaine and other drug use (e.g., alcohol, heroin, or amphetamines) can trigger chorea and hallucinations, which are also seen here. However, it has been one year since the patient last used cocaine. Her symptoms should have improved or remained the same, but they would not have progressed further.

G) CORRECT:

Huntington disease (HD) affects the indirect pathway of the striatum to the globus pallidus externus, which leads to excess cortical activity, manifesting with chorea and hyperkinetic movements (often mistaken for restlessness) classically beginning at about 40 years of age. As the disease progresses, cognitive and behavioral changes occur that manifest as dementia with primarily impaired executive functioning and depression with suicidal tendencies. As HD progresses, both direct and indirect pathways become affected. Movement dysfunction then transforms into a hypokinetic/akinetic movement disorder, including dystonia (e.g. delayed return to neutral with plantar reflex) and motor impersistence (e.g. inability to maintain tongue protrusion). Hallucinations can be present at any stage of the disease. HD classically is associated with genetic anticipation. Although conclusive evidence would require genetic testing, the suicide of this patient's father suggests inheritance.

See “Differential diagnosis of choreoathetoid movement disorders” table.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is caused by an increased number of CAG repeats on chromosome 4.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of involuntary movements of her extremities. One year ago, she was fired from her position as an elementary school teacher because she had stopped preparing lessons and was frequently absent without notice. She now lives with her mother. She appears emaciated and malodorous. Examination shows rapid, nonrepetitive jerks of her limbs and face that frequently end with the patient covering her face and yawning. She has an unsteady gait. Genetic testing shows a mutation on chromosome 4. This patient's condition is most likely associated with increased levels of which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A reduced level of glutamate has been observed in the cingulate cortex of patients with Huntington disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with Huntington disease have a profoundly decreased (not increased) GABA level in the striatum (caudate and putamen), globus pallidus, and substantia nigra. Decreased GABA levels have also been observed in anxiety disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Reduced levels of acetylcholine have been observed in the striatum of patients with Huntington disease. Likewise, cholinergic transmission is reduced in Alzheimer disease.

D) CORRECT:

Increased dopaminergic transmission has been observed in the early phases of Huntington disease leading to hyperkinetic movements, as seen in this patient. Huntington disease involves selective degeneration of medium spiny neurons in the caudate and putamen, preferentially affecting the indirect pathway of the basal ganglia in the early stages of the disease. In the late phase of HD, there is dopamine depletion, which leads to the development of bradykinesia and rigidity.

E) INCORRECT:

Levels of N-acetyl aspartate are reduced in patients with early Huntington disease, mild cognitive impairment, and Alzheimer disease.
questions.hint: The patient's apparent changes in personality, mood, and/or cognitive function (recent termination of her job, lack of personal hygiene) and the finding of chorea on examination are consistent with Huntington disease (HD). HD is an autosomal dominant progressive neurodegenerative disorder caused by a trinucleotide expansion of CAG in the Huntington gene on chromosome 4p.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman, accompanied by her husband, presents to establish care. She reports experiencing some depressed mood during the past 6 months, but her main concerns are memory difficulties and involuntary movements that have developed during the same period. These symptoms are intermittent, without loss of consciousness, slurred speech, motor weakness, numbness, tingling, or post-ictal confusion. The patient’s husband notes that she has also had restless sleep and weight loss during the past month.
She otherwise has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She consumes fewer than two alcoholic beverages per month and does not use tobacco or recreational drugs. Her father died by suicide at age 42; her mother is alive at age 68 with a history of stroke and hypothyroidism.
On physical examination, the patient has normal vital signs but appears to be restless. On neurologic examination, her tone, muscle strength, and sensation are all normal, but she has frequent, random, brief jerking movements of both the arms and face and occasional writhing movements of the right leg. She has hyperreflexia of the deep-tendon reflexes of the biceps, knees, and ankles. The rest of the physical examination is normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis is a demyelinating disease whose most common neurologic symptoms are visual, motor, or sensory-related. It is associated with depression and mood changes, but chorea would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Tourette syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder that often surfaces during childhood and is characterized by uncontrollable motor and vocal tics. Many patients with this syndrome have mood or anxiety disorders, but progressive dementia would not be typical.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is most consistent with Huntington disease, an inherited neurodegenerative condition characterized by uncontrollable jerky movements, progressive cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms such as anxiety, depression, and psychosis. Physical examination in affected patients typically does not reveal any focal findings other than the characteristic chorea and diffuse hyperreflexia. Cognitive disturbances may appear years before the other symptoms, but they are often too subtle for detection. Huntington disease overwhelmingly affects quality of life, with patients requiring 24-hour care as the disease progresses; it eventually leads to premature death due to complications of immobility.

Key learning point: Huntington disease manifests with a triad of uncontrollable movements (chorea), progressive cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms — and may be associated with a known family history of the disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a degenerative disease affecting motor neurons. It manifests with muscle weakness and atrophy or bulbar symptoms, with fasciculations (muscle twitches) present on physical examination. Chorea, as seen in this case, is not characteristic of ALS.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

E) INCORRECT:

Vascular dementia typically manifests with progressive cognitive decline and mild cognitive impairment. Focal neurologic deficits may be found on examination depending on the geographic location of the disrupted blood flow; the diffuse findings noted in this patient are not consistent with vascular dementia.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman is brought to the office for worsening depressed mood and irritability for several months. Her husband has also noticed shaky movements of her limbs and trunk for the past year. Her father died by suicide at the age of 45 years. The patient has no suicidal ideation. She registers 3/3 words but can recall only one word 5 minutes later. Examination shows irregular, involuntary movements of the arms and legs at rest. Slit-lamp examination shows no abnormalities. Muscle strength and reflexes are normal bilaterally. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Babinski sign indicates an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Other common UMN signs include weakness, hyperreflexia, and spasticity. Although patients with advanced HD may develop UMN signs, the later stages of the disease are usually characterized by hypokinetic motor symptoms rather than chorea. Oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid are characteristic of multiple sclerosis (MS). This patient's neurological symptoms are chronic and progressive without focal deficits, which is uncommon for MS. In addition, MS does not typically cause choreoathetoid movements.

C) INCORRECT:

Temporoparietal hypometabolism on PET scan is characteristic of Alzheimer disease (AD), which is a common cause of short term memory loss (e.g., poor word recall) and is frequently associated with depressive symptoms. However, AD typically affects patients > 65 years of age and manifests with pronounced language and temporospatial symptoms (e.g., disorientation). In addition, AD does not cause choreoathetoid movements.

D) CORRECT:

Atrophy of the striatum, especially in the caudate nucleus, with consequent enlargement of ventricles (i.e., ex vacuo ventriculomegaly) is characteristic of HD. Neuroimaging is primarily used to rule out other intracranial causes of a patient's symptoms rather than to diagnose HD. When HD is suspected, genetic testing (e.g., via PCR) is the test of choice.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted FSPGR; coronal view)

There is an enlargement of the ventricles and subarachnoid space as well as volume loss of cortex and caudate nuclei heads (green overlay) that usually have a convex shape (dotted white line). These findings are typical of general cerebral atrophy. The frontal horns of the lateral ventricles (gray hatched overlay) are enlarged due to the cerebral atrophy, giving them a box-like configuration.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased ceruloplasmin is characteristic of Wilson disease (WD), which leads to copper accumulation in certain parts of the CNS (e.g., subcortical white matter, cerebral cortex, basal ganglia), causing symptoms similar to those seen in HD (i.e., mood changes, cognitive impairment, and movement disorders). The vast majority of patients with WD who have neurological symptoms also present with Kayser-Fleischer rings on slit-lamp examination. The absence of Kayser-Fleischer rings in this patient makes WD unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's chorea (e.g., involuntary limb and trunk movements), depression, irritability, and cognitive impairment (e.g., word recall difficulty) are suggestive of Huntington disease (HD).

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is brought to the office by her husband because of a 2-year history of abnormal behavior. During this time she has been irritable, and restless, and has had multiple episodes of hearing voices. She has a 2-year history of depression. Her father died by suicide at the age of 50 years. Neurologic examination shows a delayed return to neutral ankle position after triggering the plantar reflex. Physical examination shows irregular, nonrepetitive, and arrhythmic movements of the neck and head. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with Wilson disease may present with mood changes, dysarthria, movement disorders, cognitive impairment, and depression. However, motor symptoms typically include asymmetrical tremor, parkinsonism, and/or dystonia; choreiform movements would be unlikely. In addition, the condition usually presents earlier in life (between 5 and 35 years) and is associated with characteristic physical exam findings of copper accumulation (e.g., Kayser-Fleischer rings, hepatomegaly, jaundice), which are not seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a neurodegenerative disease that may also manifest with hallucinations, depression, involuntary movements, and mood changes. However, this disease usually progresses much faster than this patient's condition, with an average life expectancy of fewer than 12 months following symptom onset. While choreiform movements can occur in CJD, myoclonic movements are far more common. Furthermore, this patient does not present other clinical features of CJD, such as mutism, seizures, and gait disturbance.

C) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease (PD) can also present with a slow progression of involuntary movements with lower limb rigidity, dysphagia, depression, cognitive impairment, dysarthria, and mood disorders. However, this patient is younger than most individuals at symptom onset of PD (age of onset ∼ 60 years) and her physical exam shows choreiform movements rather than the typical 4–6 Hz pill-rolling hand tremor and bradykinesia.

D) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) also commonly occurs in women between 20–40 years of age and manifests with depression, dysphagia, cognitive impairment, hyperreflexia, and speech impairment. However, MS is usually characterized by episodes of demyelination symptoms (e.g., loss of proprioception or vibration, Lhermitte sign, upper motor neuron weakness), cranial nerve palsy, intention tremor, and/or ophthalmological symptoms (optic neuritis, internuclear ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus), not by choreiform movements. Symptomatic episodes of MS are classically separated by periods of remission; progressive symptoms, as seen in this patient, are less common.

E) CORRECT:

Huntington disease (HD) affects the indirect pathway of the striatum to the globus pallidus externus, which leads to excess cortical activity, manifesting with chorea and hyperkinetic movements (often mistaken for restlessness) classically beginning at about 40 years of age. As the disease progresses, cognitive and behavioral changes occur that manifest as dementia with primarily impaired executive functioning and depression with suicidal tendencies. As HD progresses, both direct and indirect pathways become affected. Movement dysfunction then transforms into a hypokinetic/akinetic movement disorder, including dystonia (e.g. delayed return to neutral with plantar reflex) and motor impersistence (e.g. inability to maintain tongue protrusion). Hallucinations can be present at any stage of the disease. HD classically is associated with genetic anticipation. Although conclusive evidence would require genetic testing, the suicide of this patient's father suggests inheritance.

See “Differential diagnosis of choreoathetoid movement disorders” table.

Key learning point: Huntington disease is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder characterized by adult-onset chorea, psychiatric symptoms, cognitive decline, and a family history of similar symptoms or suicide.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is caused by an increased number of CAG repeats on chromosome 4.

questions.text: You are seeing a 42-year-old woman who is brought to your clinic by her husband because of a 2-year history of abnormal behavior. During this period, she has been irritable, restless, and has experienced multiple episodes of auditory hallucinations. She also has a 2-year history of depression. Her father died by suicide at age 50. Neurologic examination reveals a delayed return to neutral ankle position after triggering the plantar reflex. On physical examination, she has irregular, nonrepetitive, and arrhythmic movements of the neck and head. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

As HD progresses, both direct and indirect pathways become affected. Movement dysfunction then transforms into a hypokinetic/akinetic movement disorder, including dystonia (e.g. delayed return to neutral with plantar reflex) and motor impersistence (e.g. inability to maintain tongue protrusion). See “Differential diagnosis of choreoathetoid movement disorders” table.

Key learning point: Huntington disease is an inherited neurodegenerative disorder characterized by adult-onset chorea, psychiatric symptoms, cognitive decline, and a family history of similar findings or suicide.

Patients with Wilson disease may present with mood changes, dysarthria, movement disorders, cognitive impairment, and depression. However, this patient is younger than most individuals at symptom onset of PD (age of onset ∼ 60 years) and her physical exam shows choreiform movements rather than the typical 4–6 Hz pill-rolling hand tremor and bradykinesia.

Furthermore, this patient does not present other clinical features of CJD, such as mutism, seizures, and gait disturbance.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) also commonly occurs in women between 20–40 years of age and manifests with depression, dysphagia, cognitive impairment, hyperreflexia, and speech impairment. However, MS is usually characterized by episodes of demyelination symptoms (e.g., loss of proprioception or vibration, Lhermitte sign, upper motor neuron weakness), cranial nerve palsy, intention tremor, and/or ophthalmological symptoms (optic neuritis, internuclear ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus), not by choreiform movements. Symptomatic episodes of MS are classically separated by periods of remission; progressive symptoms, as seen in this patient, are less common.

questions.text: You are seeing a 37-year-old woman who is brought to your clinic for several months of worsening depressed mood and irritability. Her husband reports that she has had shaky movements of her limbs and trunk for the past year. Her father died by suicide at age 45. She denies suicidal ideation. On cognitive testing, she registers 3/3 words but recalls only one word after 5 minutes. Examination reveals irregular, involuntary movements of the arms and legs at rest. Slit-lamp examination is normal. Muscle strength and reflexes are normal bilaterally. Further evaluation is most likely to show which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Babinski sign indicates an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Other common UMN signs include weakness, hyperreflexia, and spasticity. Although patients with advanced HD may develop UMN signs, the later stages of the disease are usually characterized by hypokinetic motor symptoms rather than chorea. A Babinski sign might develop later in the course of the disease, but it is an unlikely finding at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Temporoparietal hypometabolism on PET scan is characteristic of Alzheimer disease (AD), which is a common cause of short term memory loss (e.g., poor word recall) and is frequently associated with depressive symptoms. However, AD typically affects patients > 65 years of age and manifests with pronounced language and temporospatial symptoms (e.g., disorientation). In addition, AD does not cause choreoathetoid movements.

Decreased ceruloplasmin is characteristic of Wilson disease (WD), which leads to copper accumulation in certain parts of the CNS (e.g., subcortical white matter, cerebral cortex, basal ganglia), causing symptoms similar to those seen in HD (i.e., mood changes, cognitive impairment, and movement disorders). The vast majority of patients with WD who have neurological symptoms also present with Kayser-Fleischer rings on slit-lamp examination. The absence of Kayser-Fleischer rings in this patient makes WD unlikely.

Atrophy of the striatum, especially in the caudate nucleus, with consequent enlargement of ventricles (i.e., ex vacuo ventriculomegaly) is characteristic of HD. Neuroimaging is primarily used to rule out other intracranial causes of a patient's symptoms rather than to diagnose HD. When HD is suspected, genetic testing (e.g., via PCR) is the test of choice.

Key learning point: Huntington disease is characterized by caudate nucleus atrophy on MRI.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted FSPGR; coronal view)

There is an enlargement of the ventricles and subarachnoid space as well as volume loss of cortex and caudate nuclei heads (green overlay) that usually have a convex shape (dotted white line). These findings are typical of general cerebral atrophy. The frontal horns of the lateral ventricles (gray hatched overlay) are enlarged due to the cerebral atrophy, giving them a box-like configuration.

This condition is known as hydrocephalus ex vacuo. These findings in a patient with chorea are consistent with Huntington disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid are characteristic of multiple sclerosis (MS). This patient's neurological symptoms are chronic and progressive without focal deficits, which is uncommon for MS. In addition, MS does not typically cause choreoathetoid movements.
questions.hint: This patient's chorea (e.g., involuntary limb and trunk movements), depression, irritability, and cognitive impairment (e.g., word recall difficulty) are suggestive of Huntington disease (HD).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with an 8-month history of involuntary movements affecting her face, arms, and trunk. She demonstrates sudden, irregular, jerking movements that shift unpredictably between body regions and writhing movements of the hands. Her husband reports increasing clumsiness and occasional inappropriate emotional responses. She has also had urinary incontinence for the past month. She has no known medical history and takes no medications. Vital signs are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sydenham chorea is a CNS manifestation of rheumatic fever that typically manifests with muscle weakness and involuntary movements and usually affects children, especially girls. This patient's age (45 years) and absence of fever or other systemic symptoms make Sydenham chorea unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Wilson disease typically manifests with asymmetrical tremor, parkinsonism, and dystonia rather than the irregular, shifting choreiform movements described in this patient. Additionally, Wilson disease commonly manifests with signs of liver disease (e.g., jaundice, hepatomegaly) and signs of copper deposition such as Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are not described in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical presentation is classic for Huntington disease. The patient demonstrates chorea (involuntary, sudden, irregular movements shifting between body regions) and athetosis (writhing movements of the hands), which characterize the initial stages of this condition. The behavioral changes (inappropriate emotional responses) and urinary incontinence are consistent with autonomic symptoms and early psychiatric manifestations that occur in Huntington disease, typically affecting middle-aged adults ∼ 40 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

While systemic lupus erythematosus can cause choreoathetoid movements, it most commonly affects women of childbearing age and typically manifests with additional systemic features such as arthritis, skin lesions, photosensitive rash, oral ulcers, and cardiovascular or renal disorders. This patient does not have the characteristic multisystem manifestations of lupus, making systemic lupus erythematosus unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced chorea typically manifests with twisting movements of the tongue and fingers, lip-smacking, and chewing movements, often caused by medications such as levodopa, oral contraceptives, or antipsychotics. This patient takes no medications, and the movement pattern described is more consistent with a different condition.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is brought to the ED by her husband for sudden involuntary movements of her arms and legs and occasional difficulty swallowing. He reports an 18-month history of increasingly erratic behavior, including inappropriate emotional responses and difficulty concentrating at work. She has not seen a doctor about her symptoms because she lost her job 11 months ago and no longer has health insurance. Her father died of an unknown, protracted illness at 52 years of age. On examination, she exhibits brief, irregular movements of her limbs and cannot maintain tongue protrusion when asked. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Referral for genetic counseling and testing
Serum ceruloplasmin level and 24-hour urine copper

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with early signs of Huntington disease including motor impersistence, chorea, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and a concerning family history. Genetic testing for CAG repeat expansion is the definitive diagnostic test, and genetic counseling is essential given the hereditary nature and implications for family members.

B) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibody testing is indicated when systemic lupus erythematosus is suspected, but this condition typically affects women of childbearing age with systemic manifestations such as arthritis and skin lesions. The episodes of chorea and motor impersistence suggest a hereditary movement disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture may be considered to evaluate for infectious or inflammatory causes of movement disorders or to test for 14-3-3 protein in suspected Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. This patient's concerning family history and symptoms of chorea and movement impersistence make an alternative diagnosis more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

A DaTSCAN, an imaging technique used to visualize striatal dopamine transporters, may be used for the diagnosis of Parkinson disease. The patient's symptoms are more consistent with Huntington disease than Parkinson disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum ceruloplasmin level and urine copper studies are used to diagnose Wilson disease, which can manifest with movement disorders and neuropsychiatric symptoms. However, Wilson disease typically includes signs of liver disease and copper deposition such as Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are not described in this patient.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife who is concerned about his worsening condition. She reports that over the past 6 months he has developed involuntary, sudden, and irregular movements of his arms and face that have progressively interfered with his daily activities. The movements are nonrepetitive and arrhythmic. His wife mentions that his father died in his 50s from a "neurological condition" but she doesn't recall specifics. On examination, you observe brief, jerky movements affecting his limbs and facial muscles that appear to flow randomly from one part of his body to another. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While movement disorders may occasionally result from stimulant use, the 6-month progressive course and characteristic pattern of chorea with possible family history make drug intoxication unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

 Antipsychotic medications may provide symptomatic relief for choreiform movements, but initiating treatment without establishing a definitive diagnosis is inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Brain imaging is rarely used for diagnosing this condition and would not provide the definitive information needed.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – The presentation of progressive chorea in a middle-aged patient with possible family history strongly suggests Huntington disease. Genetic testing via polymerase chain reaction provides definitive diagnosis, and neurology referral ensures appropriate management and genetic counseling.

E) INCORRECT:

The movement pattern described represents chorea rather than the bradykinesia and rigidity associated with Parkinson disease. Dopaminergic therapy would not address the underlying pathophysiology and could potentially exacerbate choreiform movements.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his wife due to a one-year history of increasing irritability and impulsivity. She also notes he has developed "fidgety," dance-like movements of his limbs and face. His father had a similar neurologic condition that began in his 40s. On examination, the patient displays brief, irregular, non-repetitive movements of his face and extremities. With disease progression, this patient is most likely to develop which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fasciculations and progressive muscle weakness are characteristic findings of motor neuron diseases, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). ALS primarily affects upper and lower motor neurons, leading to weakness and atrophy, but it does not cause the choreiform movements or the specific cognitive and psychiatric profile seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

A pill-rolling resting tremor is a cardinal feature of Parkinson disease, a hypokinetic movement disorder resulting from dopamine depletion in the substantia nigra. This patient presents with chorea, which is a hyperkinetic movement, and a clinical picture inconsistent with Parkinson disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Pain with eye movements is a hallmark symptom of optic neuritis, a condition strongly associated with multiple sclerosis. This patient's presentation of a progressive movement disorder with psychiatric changes and a specific family history is not suggestive of multiple sclerosis.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical picture of chorea, psychiatric disturbances (irritability, impulsivity), and a strong family history is classic for Huntington disease. This autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder is caused by a CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the huntingtin gene, leading to atrophy of the caudate nucleus and putamen. The disease is characterized by a triad of motor, psychiatric, and cognitive symptoms. Cognitive decline, particularly impaired executive function, is a core feature in advanced stages of disease. This manifests as difficulty with planning, organizing, multitasking, and impulse control, which aligns with the history of impulsivity. Other cognitive deficits include slowed processing speed and memory impairment.

E) INCORRECT:

An intention tremor, which worsens as a limb approaches a target, is a classic sign of cerebellar dysfunction. Although various movement abnormalities can occur in this patient's condition, a prominent intention tremor is not a characteristic feature. The movements described are choreiform, not a rhythmic tremor associated with purposeful action.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of personality changes over the past year. He has become increasingly irritable, loud, aggressive, and impulsive. His wife also reports jerky movements of his limbs and trunk for the past few months. His father had dementia in his mid-40s, but the details of his condition are unclear. The patient appears restless. Examination shows irregular movements of the extremities and twitching of the face and tongue. Mental status examination shows impaired memory. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following changes on MRI?

choices.text: Degeneration of the frontal and temporal lobes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reduced volume of the hippocampus can be seen on brain MRI in patients with Alzheimer dementia (AD). Even though familial forms of AD (e.g., with presenilin-1 mutation) can manifest in middle-aged patients such as this man, early symptoms would include impaired short-term memory and depressed mood, not impulsive behavior. Furthermore, AD would not account for the presence of chorea in this patient.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbance

Medial temporal lobe atrophy is accompanied by widening of the subarachnoid space (green overlay) and dilatation of the temporal horns of the lateral ventricles (red overlay).

These morphologic changes have been observed in the setting of Alzheimer disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Multiple cortical and subcortical infarctions on brain imaging are characteristic of vascular dementia, which would manifest with a stepwise deterioration of mental capacity, similar to what this patient is experiencing in that it would be progressive. It could also explain his abnormal behavior; however, it would not present with chorea, and he does not have any significant atherosclerotic risk factors to predispose him to cerebral ischemia.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Abnormal low attenuation areas (green overlay) are seen in the periventricular white matter. Two frontal lacunar infarcts (arrowheads) are also present.

These findings may be seen in vascular dementia.

C) INCORRECT:

Degeneration of the frontal and temporal lobes occurs in frontotemporal dementia (FTD). This patient's memory impairment, personality changes (particularly his disinhibited and impulsive behavior), and the hereditary component could likely all be attributed to FTD. However, the presence of chorea suggests a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view)

There is atrophy of the left frontal (FL) and temporal lobe (TL) with prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces (green overlay).

As the name suggests, frontotemporal dementia predominantly affects the frontal and temporal lobes. The specific pattern of brain atrophy varies by subtype. Although cerebral atrophy is often bilateral in frontotemporal dementia, it can be asymmetrical, as demonstrated in this example.

Because the majority of people develop some degree of brain atrophy as a part of normal aging, correlation with the clinical history is essential for this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Periventricular plaques on brain MRI in combination with neurologic dysfunction are diagnostic of multiple sclerosis (MS), which, as a very late feature, is associated with cognitive impairment, including memory deficits and depression. The majority of affected individuals have relapsing-remitting MS and experience alternating flare-ups with near complete remission of symptoms, rather than the continuous, progressive pattern seen in this patient. This patient has no history of symptoms that would suggest MS (e.g., impaired vision, diplopia, or sensory disturbances). Furthermore, MS is not associated with chorea.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane)

Extensive bilateral demyelinating lesions (plaques) appear as hyperintensities in the periventricular white matter (green overlay). Radial extensions of these lesions (Dawson fingers) are visible. Generalized cerebral atrophy, part of the disease process for multiple sclerosis, is also visible.

E) INCORRECT:

An extra-axial tumor with dural attachments is consistent with a meningioma. Though meningiomas are initially asymptomatic in most patients due to their slow growth, a symptomatic meningioma could manifest with a variety of neurological symptoms, including mental status change, due to mass effect of the tumor on the surrounding structures. However, memory impairment and chorea would not be expected in meningioma.
Image Description:

MRI Head (T1 weighted; with contrast; coronal plane)

There is a well-circumscribed, homogeneously enhancing rounded mass (green overlay) continuous with the falx cerebri and dura of the right parietal bone. It does not invade the surrounding brain tissue or bone.

This is a case of meningioma. This is the most common diagnosis for a dural-based mass with smooth margins and homogeneous contrast enhancement. Other important differentials include lymphoma and metastasis, both of which would more likely (but not always) be less uniform in shape and enhanceheterogeneously.

F) CORRECT:

Atrophy of the striatum, specifically the caudate nucleus and putamen, is a classic finding on brain imaging in patients with Huntington disease (HD). HD is caused by CAG trinucleotide repeats in the huntingtin gene, which cause aggregates of abnormal huntingtin protein to accumulate, resulting in neuronal death and gliosis in the striatum. The disorder is diagnosed via genetic testing, with neuroimaging used to rule out other intracranial pathologies.

The father, in this case, became ill later and possibly less severely than the son, a fact that can be attributed to the phenomenon of anticipation (genetics), a characteristic of trinucleotide repeat disorders.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted FSPGR; coronal view)

There is an enlargement of the ventricles and subarachnoid space as well as volume loss of cortex and caudate nuclei heads (green overlay) that usually have a convex shape (dotted white line). These findings are typical of general cerebral atrophy. The frontal horns of the lateral ventricles (gray hatched overlay) are enlarged due to the cerebral atrophy, giving them a box-like configuration.

This condition is known as hydrocephalus ex vacuo. These findings in a patient with chorea are consistent with Huntington disease.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has Huntington disease (HD) based on the presence of chorea (e.g., involuntary limb and trunk movements), behavioral changes (aggression, impulsivity), and cognitive impairments (impaired memory). His father's dementia may have also been associated with HD, which would be consistent with the autosomal dominant inheritance pattern of the condition.
